opener.dateline: 1841 9 Hatch Street Dublin when="1841-05-30"> cert="high"> May 30, 1841

div.p: A welcome, more welcome more delightfully welcome to me could not have met my eyes than the note in your own dear handwriting

I hope it did not give you horrid pain to write it? And so much! and so well written as if you had never been ill -- whatever it cost you believe me you have given me heartfelt pleasure and more than pleasure - satisfaction.

Harriet Beaufort told you yes terday what Crampton says about the care you ought to take not to exert yourself or to do any thing that distresses you standing sitting -- or moving -- How angry he would have been had he four pages in your own hand.
Dearest mother thank you thank you - I will not give you an opportunity of doing the like again for I will be with you soon & then you can only sin by talking or hearing too much

I left London without any anxiety about Fanny as I had to the very last day and hour satisfactory accounts of her progressing - or or at least of her not back-sliding I enclose two [underline]billet doux[/underline] from her & of her for the pleasure of your eyes -
I set off from London, from the Railroad station at 9 oclock -

Kind Lestock having brought me bag & baggage and all to the right point at the right minute and there was Charles Fox ready for me having taken our two places in the Coupee - Only costs 2Sh a piece more than in the 1[superscript]s[/superscript] class other carriages & it is delightfully comfortable - as good as any gentleman's chariot is or need to be & as dear & large windows & green curtains & all that most luxurious [underline]exclusive[/underline] could want or wish for excluding sun into the bargain or not as you like - A most pleasant journey I had - the easiness of the motion on the rail way from Birming ham to Liverpool resting me complete ly after the roughness and great joggling of the rail-road from London to Birmingham - Francis may remember that I observed this difference when I travelled with him & now I have verified it. Tho
we came all through in one day from London to Liv.[superscript]l[/superscript] I was not the least tired [insertion]arrived at 1/2 after 5 at Liverpool Liverpool[/insertion] - We had but just time to get from Liv[superscript]l[/superscript] Rail road station in fly to steam packet & by C Fox's manual exertions to get my 4 boxes & 1 bag & his own (including two rolls of window curtain chintz of his, so barba rously ill done up that they were forever slipping out of their [underline]silver [/underline]paper only covering The Recorder F. Shaw & Col.[superscript]l[/superscript] Conolly, and Sir William Betham & 2 other members of parl. (names forgotten) were on board the packet & gathered round Charles & me - and talked an immensity of politics [deletion]&c[/deletion] - Peel and Dissolution &c &c - Literature & compliments for me interspersed more than quantum suff - And I was glad at last even to get down to my close birth - with 2 quakers & their bonnets and a [unclear]lady [/unclear] contrast [insertion]in colors[/insertion] - all very quiet and all fell fast asleep - And nobody stirred till morning 6 oclock & a very fine morning and as calm a night as would be - [deletion][/deletion] a ten & half hours passage - C Fox brought me to this nice house and dear Harriet ready dressed at the door by 1/4 before 8 - and she welcomed me with her own smiles and your note - I had had coffee before I quitted Steampacket - So no hurry for breakfast & took Harriets advice & lay down for half an hour & then washed & refreshed & no more tired than if I had
